facts.text: Appellant appointed Resident Engineer for Light Houses and posted to Bombay in 1954, due to retire in January 1955 but given extensions from time to time.
Complainant M.M. Patel, a building contractor, submitted tender for reconstruction of lighthouse at Tolkeshwar Point on March 21, 1956; tender accepted on June 30, 1956; work order issued.
Complainant commenced work in November 1956.
Overseer supervising work not satisfied with contractor's manner; in December 1956, appellant warned complainant to carry out work according to specifications.
Near lighthouse construction site: temple of Tolkeshwar, attached dharmashala, well (only convenient water source, water up to 6 feet depth).

In 1957, appellant wrote to temple trustee for permission to take water from well for Government staff; trustee (Mr. Gole) suggested deepening well and no objection to pipeline if water supplied to temple/dharmashala.
Well not deepened by Government; admitted that contractor used well water without express permission; by end of work, water level down to below 2 feet.
Complainant alleged appellant demanded bribe in February 1957 during visit to Tolkeshwar; both courts found no visit in February 1957.
High Court held appellant demanded bribe in June 1957 during visit to Tolkeshwar; complainant mistaken on date.
Bhatia posted as Overseer on March 26, 1957; first running bill cheque Rs. 7,278 given March 30, 1957; Bhatia complained April 2, 1957 about unsatisfactory work and lack of supervision facilities.
Assistant Engineer inspected work April 6, 1957, found faults.
April 7, 1957: complainant and workmen assaulted Bhatia; Bhatia complained in writing to appellant; forwarded to higher authorities who reprimanded complainant, required undertaking.
April 9, 1957: appellant instructed Bhatia to give written instructions to complainant; instructed complainant to follow Bhatia and not use force.
May 13, 1957: appellant reported to Director General of Lighthouses that work bad, not per specifications; suggested pulling down structures.
Complainant protested; second running bill Rs. 38,000 presented May 28, 1957; cheque prepared but not handed over due to defective work.
August 1, 1957: Director General instructed appellant not to make payment to complainant.
After correspondence, complainant pulled down defective structures, reconstructed; paid Rs. 27,569 on February 6, 1958 after appellant's favourable report January 10, 1958.
Further payments: Rs. 35,000 (March 18, 1958), Rs. 7,000, Rs. 21,000, Rs. 6,200, Rs. 9,190, Rs. 18,900 (up to February 9, 1959); no suggestion of bribe demand before these.

Prosecution: January 5, 1959, appellant asked complainant's brother-in-law Jaikishen for Rs. 300-400 during absence of complainant; not paid, pretext no funds; story disbelieved by Special Judge, no reference in High Court.
Appellant asked complainant to level ground adjoining staff quarters and deepen well (extra work); complainant declined; also asked to repair temple/dharmashala, refused.
February 9, 1959: ninth running bill Rs. 22,000 presented.
March 13, 1959: appellant visited Tolkeshwar, received letter from D.S. Apte (DW2, temple caretaker) requesting repairs, painting, water tap, road for temple.
Appellant suggested complainant do some work free for temple; complainant resided in dharmashala, used temple hall for cement, used well water.
Cheque for ninth bill Rs. 22,000 prepared March 23, 1959 but not handed over.
Prosecution: appellant demanded 10% of bills, reduced to 3-4%, then Rs. 1,000; withheld cheque to compel payment.

Appellant: refused certification unless complainant undertook extra work (levelling, deepening well); extra work under contract, entitled to separate payment; asked complainant to see him in Bombay March 26, 1959.
March 27, 1959: complainant wrote postcard not to send cheque by post, hand over personally in Bombay.
March 28, 1959: appellant endorsed postcard, asked complainant to see him April 6, 1959 for cheque.
March 31, 1959: appellant learnt of tenth bill cheque Rs. 32,200 prepared; not handed over.
Complainant lodged complaint with anti-corruption department.

April 6, 1959: complainant saw appellant in cabin; appellant handed cheque; complainant paid Rs. 1,000 in currency notes (anthracene powder smeared); police entered, recovered notes from appellant's pocket; traces on appellant's pocket, fingers, complainant's fingers, notes.
Cheque not subjected to anthracene test.
Appellant's explanation: after handing cheque, complainant said can't do temple repairs due to lack of men, handed Rs. 1,000 for temple authorities.
Receipt of Rs. 1,000 admitted, not legal remuneration.
Appellant applied for retirement as from June 30, 1959 on March 19, 1959.
Bombay High Court affirmed conviction and sentences under s.161 IPC and s.5(1)d PCA r/w s.5(2) PCA, dated August 3, 1960.
Special Judge sentenced to 1 year imprisonment.

legal_issues.text: Whether the presumption under s.4(1) of Prevention of Corruption Act raised against appellant was rebutted by his reasonable and probable explanation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Presumption under s.4 PCA rebutted by reasonable and probable explanation that Rs.1,000 was for temple authorities, not bribe; complainant had grievances over work faults, demolition, extra work insistence; no prior bribe demands despite passing large bills; appellant near retirement, unlikely to demand trivial amount; letter from D.S. Apte supports; complainant not easily coerced.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.4 Prevention of Corruption Act; Otto George Gfeller v. The King

petitioner_arguments.text: Mere receipt of money as gratification triggers presumption, but rebuttable by reasonable probable explanation consistent with innocence.
High Court misapplied law requiring proof beyond reasonable doubt from accused, akin to prosecution burden.
Cheque not tested with anthracene, depriving defence that cheque handed before money.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant demanded bribes, including in June 1957 and for ninth bill (10% reduced to Rs.1,000); withheld cheque to compel; trap laid validly; explanation implausible.

court_reasoning.text: Presumption under s.4(1) PCA arises upon proof of receipt of gratification other than legal remuneration; mere money receipt suffices, no need to prove incriminating character initially.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prosecution proved receipt of Rs.1,000 not legal remuneration.

court_reasoning.text: Presumption under s.4(1) PCA is presumption of law ('shall presume'), obligatory; rebutted only by proof that contrary is true, not mere reasonable probable explanation; accused must establish explanation as true, not just create doubt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguished from s.114 Evidence Act presumption of fact.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant's explanation not proved true; letter from Apte and his evidence insufficient; no evidence appellant authorized to collect for temple; High Court reasonably disbelieved complainant demand story but rejected defence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Question of fact; High Court assessment not erroneous.

holdings.text: Presumption under s.4(1) Prevention of Corruption Act arises on proof of receipt of money not legal remuneration; rebuttable only by proof contrary is true, not mere plausible explanation.
Appellant's explanation not rebutting presumption; conviction affirmed.

precedents_cited.case_name: C.I. Emden v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Mere receipt of money other than legal remuneration triggers s.4(1) presumption; 'gratification' does not require proving bribe initially.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. A. Vaidyanatha Iyer
precedents_cited.relevance: s.4(1) is presumption of law ('shall presume'); rebutted only by disproof, not probability; shifts onus to accused.

precedents_cited.case_name: Otto George Gfeller v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Applies to presumptions of fact (e.g., s.114 Evidence Act); not to statutory presumption of law under s.4(1) PCA.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences of bribery; presumption that gratification as motive/reward for s.161.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Presumption on receipt of gratification; offence of criminal misconduct.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Presumption of fact (may presume) distinguished from presumption of law (shall presume).

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave against Bombay High Court judgment affirming conviction under s.161 IPC and s.5(1)(d) r/w s.5(2) PCA; held presumption under s.4(1) PCA not rebutted; plea to reduce sentence considering age and near-retirement rejected as Special Judge already gave minimum 1 year RI.

key_quotes.text: "unless the contrary is proved that he accepted or obtained... as a motive or reward such as is mentioned in the said section 161" - s.4(1) PCA.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Triggers mandatory presumption on proof of receipt.

key_quotes.text: The burden resting on the accused... cannot be held to be discharged merely by reason of the fact that the explanation offered by the accused is reasonable and probable. It must further be shown that the explanation is a true one.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines standard to rebut s.4(1) presumption.

key_quotes.text: "Shall presume has been defined... as proved unless and until it is disproved."
key_quotes.speaker: court
